#Text=Pelin Ünker
#Text=Pelin Ünker speaks in 2019
#Text=Pelin Ünker ( [ pɛˈlin ynˈkɛr ] ) is a Turkish journalist and a member of the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists .
#Text=In the late 2010s she investigated the Turkish dimension of the Paradise Papers affair . [ 1 ]
#Text=She has worked for the Cumhuriyet newspaper since late 2000s and reported on the Panama Papers in 2016 , [ 2 ]

#Text=but she left her job in Cumhuriyet in the aftermath of her reporting on Paradise Papers affairs in Turkey , which also led to a defamation suit against her , criticized by several international organizations as an attack on freedom of speach and press . [ 2 ] [ 3 ] [ 4 ]
#Text=By the end of 2016 , almost half of the paper 's reporters , columnists and executives had been jailed by the Erdoğan government . [ 5 ]

#Text=Cumhuriyet has since shifted its stance to align more closely with the government , with a number of its journalists sued or resigning , and its former chief editor , Can Dündar , fleeing the country . [ 2 ] [ 3 ] [ 6 ]
#Text=Since 2018 she works as a freelancer mostly associated with Turkish-language version of the Deutsche Welle . [ 6 ] [ 3 ]
#Text=Paradise Papers lawsuits
#Text=Main article : Paradise Papers

#Text=The sons of Turkey 's prime minister , Binali Yıldırım , described as " close friends " of Turkey 's president Recep Tayyip Erdoğan , are listed in the papers as having business interests in tax havens . [ 2 ]
#Text=The sons , both doing maritime business , officially set up two companies in Malta , to avoid high Turkish tax rates .
#Text=Both of the companies are registered under the names of the two sons , with the older son Erkam Yıldırım having more shares than the younger son Bülent Yıldırım in both companies .
#Text=The companies , named Hawke Bay Marine Co. Ltd. ( founded in 2004 ) and Black Eagle Marine Co. Ltd. ( founded in 2007 ) are " active " in the available detailed data . [ 7 ]
#Text=One of the companies shared an address with a company that won a $ 7 million government contract . [ 4 ]
#Text=The brothers , although publicly acknowledging those facts , [ 8 ] sued journalist Pelin Ünker and the newspaper Cumhuriyet in 2018 after they published the story describing their involvement .
#Text=In January 2019 a Turkish court sentenced Ünker to thirteen months in jail for " defamation and insult of public official " , and separately fined the newspaper for " insult " . [ 4 ] [ 9 ]
#Text=The ICIJ 's director , Gerard Ryle , criticized the sentence as an attack on free speech . [ 1 ]
#Text=She is the only journalist in the world sentenced for writing about the Paradise Papers investigation . [ 6 ] [ 3 ] [ 10 ]
#Text=Her sentencing has also been criticized by others , including the Netherlands Helsinki Committee [ 3 ] and PEN America . [ 8 ]
#Text=Her prison sentence was overturned on appeal due to a statute of limitations , but the fine was allowed to stand . [ 4 ] [ 6 ]

#Text=Ünker has also been sued by Berat Albayrak , Turkey 's finance and treasury minister and the president 's son-in-law , first over her reporting on him related to Panama Papers , and later , about his connection with the Paradise Papers revelations . [ 2 ]
#Text=Both of those lawsuits were also dismissed . [ 2 ] [ 11 ]

#Text=The Netherlands Helsinki Committee concluded that " Because of her reporting on tax evasion schemes of Turkey 's powerful , it is no longer possible for Ünker to work in Turkish mainstream media " , stressing the problems surrounding freedom of the press issues in Turkey . [ 3 ]
#Text=Following the incident , in March 2019 the One Free Press Coalition included her in the list of world 's ten most endangered journalists . [ 12 ]
#Text=In April 2019 the Investigative Reporters and Editors awarded her the Don Bolles Medal for courage . [ 13 ]
